author: By Angeline Boulley
title: 6 Thought-Provoking Y.A. Thrillers That Tackle Social Issues
description: Angeline Boulley, the author of “Firekeeper’s Daughter” and “Warrior Girl Unearthed,” recommends exhilarating young adult books that explore important social topics.
content: I was in the sixth grade when a book changed me. I was already a voracious reader, and I loved mysteries and thrillers. Yet something was different about Robert Cormier’s 1977 novel, “I Am the Cheese.” There was an immediacy to Adam Farmer’s narration of his bike journey to visit his father. I hadn’t encountered an unreliable narrator and the lingering impact of an unsettling ending in the books I’d read before this one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Lawmakers and Former Officials Press for Answers on U.F.O.s
description: Pentagon officials have said most reported incidents involved items like airborne trash, weather balloons and drones.
content: Even by the extraordinary standards of contemporary political theater, Wednesday’s House Oversight subcommittee hearing on U.F.O.s stood out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: How Do You Personalize Your Cubicle? We Want to See It.
description: Once ridiculed as a symbol of homogeneity and ennui, the work space is popular again as employees seek privacy and quiet in the office. How have you decorated your cubicle? Share your photos with us.
content: Cubicles were once such a commoditized fixture in offices across the nation that they were used to represent the boredom of unfulfilled corporate workers in late ‘90s movies like “Being John Malkovich,” “The Matrix” and, most notably, “Office Space.” The confined spaces gradually fell out of favor as companies began to opt for fewer walls to encourage collaboration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Oregon Wildfire Destroys Dozens of Homes and Disrupts 911 Service
description: Emergency calls in Lake County, in southern Oregon, were being rerouted after the Golden fire damaged about six miles of fiber-optic cables and more than 100 power poles, officials said.
content: A wildfire in southern Oregon that started over the weekend was so intense that it disrupted 911 services and burned dozens of homes, which officials were not able to reach for days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Over 75 New York Times Graphs for Students to Analyze
description: A new collection of graphs, maps and charts organized by topic and type from our “What’s Going On in This Graph?” feature.
content: What do you notice?What do you wonder?What’s going on this graph?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Protest Scene Removed From Jason Aldean ‘Try That in a Small Town’ Video
description: A news clip of a Black Lives Matter protest in Atlanta was edited out of the music video after criticism that the song and video were offensive.
content: The music video for the song “Try That in a Small Town” by the country music star Jason Aldean appears to have been edited to remove violent images of Black Lives Matter protests after criticism that the song and the accompanying video were offensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Hans Buetow, Jen Poyant, Sara Sarasohn, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell and Marion Lozano
title: How I Lost the Fiancé but Won the Honeymoon
description: Alone on a honeymoon trip intended for her and her ex, Nell Stephens learns to leave behind the rules others set for her.
content: Bored and in love, Nell Stevens found a hobby combing the internet and entering her name into online contests. But, when she actually wins a prize — a luxury honeymoon in India — her world falls apart: The man she thought she was going to marry breaks up with her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Joe Lewis, Billionaire Owner of Tottenham Hotspur, Is Charged With Insider Trading
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan accused the British billionaire of illegally funneling nonpublic information to associates to trade on.
content: Federal prosecutors charged Joseph C. Lewis, the British billionaire who owns the Tottenham Hotspur English soccer club, with insider trading, accusing him of illegally funneling nonpublic information to associates to trade on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Sinead O’Connor’s Life in Pictures
description: The Irish singer had an evocative voice and cast a powerful silhouette onstage.
content: With her short hair and wide eyes, the Irish singer Sinead O’Connor, who has died at the age of 56, cast a powerful silhouette onstage during her music career. The height of her power came in the late 1980s and early 1990s, including a divisive 1992 appearance on “Saturday Night Live” in which she ripped up a photo of Pope John Paul II to protest sexual abuse in the Roman Catholic Church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Hiding From the Yips Will Only Make It Worse
description: Eileen Canney Linnehan was a star pitcher at Northwestern who suddenly could not throw to first base. Now she helps young athletes get through the debilitating issue.
content: Maddy Wood was an incoming freshman at Western Kentucky last fall, on scholarship, in shape and elated to pitch for the Hilltoppers. The feeling lasted only a few days, before that old, insidious anxiety gripped her. Wood could no longer throw the ball to the catcher’s glove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Batteries in E-Bikes and Other Devices Are Sparking Fires in San Francisco
description: Two people jumped out of an apartment window on Monday to escape what was the city’s 24th fire this year linked to rechargeable batteries.
content: Two people jumped out of an apartment complex window in the Tenderloin neighborhood of San Francisco to escape a fire that was spreading in their unit on Monday. One of them was seriously injured and taken to a hospital burn center, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: How Those ‘Barbie’ Dreamhouses Came to Life: ‘We All Had to Believe in It’
description: To make their Barbieland sets a reality, the movie’s production team embraced the surreal, going big on bright pinks and shrunken proportions.
content: While working on films like “Atonement,” “Anna Karenina” and “Darkest Hour,” the production designer Sarah Greenwood and the set decorator Katie Spencer, both Oscar nominees many times over, had to turn soundstages into period-accurate sets, using their extraordinary attention to detail to embroider these spaces with texture and soul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: The Night Sinead O’Connor Took on the Pope on ‘S.N.L.’
description: Tearing up a photo was the moment nobody forgot. The performance that preceded it was just as powerful.
content: What people remember about Sinead O’Connor’s Oct. 3, 1992, appearance on “Saturday Night Live” is this: At the end of her second performance of the show, a cover of Bob Marley’s “War,” O’Connor intoned gravely, “We have confidence in the victory of good over evil.” As she held tight to the word, stretching it like a castigation, she grabbed a photo of Pope John Paul II and held it up to camera. When she let the word go, she punctuated her exhale by tearing the photo three times, followed by an exhortation to “fight the real enemy.” She tossed the fragments to the ground, removed her in-ears, and stepped off the stage into culture-war infamy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Mitch McConnell Suffers an Episode at the Capitol, Freezing Midsentence
description: The 81-year-old Senate Republican leader, who had a serious fall earlier this year, was temporarily unable to speak during a news conference, raising questions about his health and future.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell, the longtime Republican leader who had a serious head injury in a fall earlier this year, froze midsentence during an appearance at his weekly news conference in the Capitol on Wednesday and was briefly escorted away from the microphones to recover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Who Is Maryellen Noreika, the Judge in the Hunter Biden Case?
description: Judge Noreika was appointed by President Donald J. Trump, but had the support of Delaware’s two Democratic senators.
content: The federal judge presiding over the Justice Department’s case against Hunter Biden is Maryellen Noreika, who serves on the United States District Court for the District of Delaware.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: After Fatal Ship Fire, Newark Mayor Wants Special Port Unit
description: Mayor Ras J. Baraka said he had begun discussions with the Port Authority and Coast Guard about creating a special team to battle shipboard fires.
content: Three weeks after two firefighters from his city died battling a blaze aboard an Italian cargo ship, the mayor of Newark said he wanted to create a unit within the fire department that would be specially trained to respond to emergencies in the city’s giant commercial port.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser and Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Russia seeks more troops.
content: Russian lawmakers on Tuesday voted to raise the top age for military conscription, aiming to expand the pool of trained recruits who could potentially join the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Iverson
title: Easy Mode: Clues for July 28
description: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
content: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: ‘Get Down’ From the Car. ‘Make’ the Line. Is Miami English a Dialect?
description: A linguistics professor found that even Miamians who aren’t fluent in Spanish use or understand phrases that are direct translations.
content: The stereotype of how many Miamians speak involves a sing-songy rhythm with a heavy-sounding “L” and a generous sprinkling of Spanglish. But what if the conversational language of South Florida were more than a lively accent? What if it were a distinct regional dialect of American English?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lily King
title: Read Your Way Through Maine
description: Reading and writing are deeply valued in Maine. The novelist Lily King recommends fiction, nature writing, memoirs, children’s books and inspiration for writers.
content: In American fiction, my state is code for outpost. Maine is where you send a character you want to get rid of, someone who goes off to raise goats, farm oysters, prep for the apocalypse — or write a novel. Apart from California, I can think of no other state in the Union that lives as strongly in the national collective imagination as a place to play out a festering dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Gap, Looking for Barbie Magic, Hires Mattel’s President as C.E.O.
description: Richard Dickson helped improve Barbie’s image, culminating in the blockbuster film. Now he faces a similar turnaround challenge at the retailer.
content: Gap hopes its new chief executive can help it achieve a Barbie-like turnaround.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Court Rejects New Sentencing for Al Qaeda Recruiter
description: Ali Hamza al-Bahlul is the only convict serving a life sentence at Guantánamo Bay. Lawyers have appealed his case six times.
content: A federal appeals court on Tuesday rejected a bid by a Yemeni prisoner at Guantánamo Bay to have a new military jury reconsider his life sentence for conspiring to commit war crimes as a propaganda chief for Al Qaeda and an aide to Osama bin Laden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Fiji’s Leader Declines Invitation to China, Saying He Tripped and Fell
description: The prime minister, wearing a bloodstained shirt, said he struck his head on a door. One analyst called it “very convenient.”
content: Fiji’s uneasy relationship with China has hit an unusual roadblock, in the form of an office door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hong
title: A Shoe Entrepreneur’s Globally Inspired Barbecue
description: Mickey Ashmore, the founder of the footwear brand Sabah, gathered friends at his Long Island ranch house for Texas ribs, Middle Eastern sides and Thai desserts.
content: Ten years ago, Mickey Ashmore was working in finance when he decided to start a side business selling handmade shoes under the label Sabah, which means “morning” in Turkish. Early on, he convinced a neighbor to let him borrow the parlor floor of her townhouse in the East Village to host Sunday afternoon trunk shows, which he called Sabah Sundays. At these convivial get-togethers, he served wine and snacks, played music and sold pair after pair of the leather slip-ons, a traditional style he had discovered while living in Istanbul between 2010 and 2012. “He had told me it would be just ‘a few friends coming over,’” Pamela Bell, the generous neighbor with the townhouse, recalled recently. “It wasn’t long before we needed a bouncer!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Joe Coscarelli
title: Sinead O’Connor, Evocative and Outspoken Singer, Is Dead at 56
description: She broke out with the single “Nothing Compares 2 U,” then caused an uproar a few years later by ripping up a photo of Pope John Paul II on “S.N.L.”
content: Sinead O’Connor, the outspoken Irish singer-songwriter known for her powerful, evocative voice, as showcased on her biggest hit, a breathtaking rendition of Prince’s “Nothing Compares 2 U,” and for her political provocations onstage and off, has died. She was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Meta Profit Is Up 16% to $7.8 Billion in Recent Quarter
description: Wall Street investors were hoping the social media giant would regain its footing after more than a year of problems, including slumping ad sales.
content: Long before it was called Meta, Facebook was a Wall Street darling because of its breakneck growth and big profits. But the company had lost its luster with investors over the past 18 months thanks to a slump in ad sales and what some saw as self-inflicted wounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: An Energy Correspondent Hunts for Alternatives
description: Ivan Penn reports on the new sources we rely on to power our world.
content: Few things cause more anxiety than flipping on the light switch only to find there’s no power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Kelso, Sarah Kerr, Shane O'Neill and Pete Gill
title: High Heat Raises Risks for Homeless Floridians
description: As Orlando, Fla., experiences what could be the hottest July on record, soaring rents and an affordable housing crisis are pushing a growing number of people onto the streets.
content: Each morning, Rickquita Monroe, 34, and Curby Monroe, 32, wake up beneath an overpass in downtown Orlando, Fla. Several other people are usually spread out beside them on the sidewalks lining either side of the five-lane road. Throughout the night, they count on gusts of wind from passing traffic for relief from the thick, increasingly blistering Florida heat. It is especially dangerous to Ms. Monroe, who has a seizure disorder that is exacerbated by high temperatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Madison Malone Kircher
title: Hollywood Strike Leaves Influencers Sidelined and Confused
description: Despite not being in the actors’ union, many content creators are passing up deals to promote films or TV shows because they don’t want to be barred from the guild or face online vitriol.
content: Deanna Giulietti is not in the actors’ union, but she turned down $28,000 last week because of its strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Wild Guess
description: Mary Crane makes her New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: When Will the Rate Hikes End?
description: Also, a new phase of Ukraine’s offensive. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Federal Reserve officials raised interest rates today to their highest level in 22 years, pressing on with a campaign to bring inflation down by cooling the American economy. The hike was widely expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: 16 People Sickened in Salmonella Outbreak Linked to Ground Beef
description: People who became ill reported eating lean ground beef that was sold at ShopRite locations in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, the C.D.C. said.
content: A salmonella outbreak linked to lean ground beef sold in ShopRite stores in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York has left 16 people sick, including six who were hospitalized, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj
title: Monsoon’s Fury Sours Romance of Wet Season Travel in India
description: Long considered a life-giving panacea, India’s rainy season has become more violent and unpredictable. It is upsetting many rhythms of life, among them, leisure travel.
content: The honeymoon, at first, was magical. Akash and Parvani Kapadi drove up pine-covered forests to a hill town in northern India with a view of the snow-capped Himalayas. In their hotel room, the gentle pitter-patter of monsoon rains on the roof set the stage for a week of romance — away from the heat and grime of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Biden Orders U.S. to Share Evidence of Russian War Crimes With Hague Court
description: The step signals a major shift in American policy and ends months of resistance by Pentagon officials who feared setting a precedent that could pave the way for the court to prosecute U.S. troops.
content: President Biden has quietly ordered the U.S. government to begin sharing evidence of Russian war crimes in Ukraine with the International Criminal Court in The Hague, according to officials familiar with the matter, signaling a major shift in American policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: A Grim Climate Lesson From the Canadian Wildfires
description: For all our plans to control emissions, humans are no longer fully in charge.
content: You may have forgotten about the Canadian wildfires, once the smoke cleared from your American lungs and the orange disappeared from American skies. But the fires have not forgotten to burn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: What to Know About Bronny James’s Cardiac Arrest
description: James was hospitalized after a cardiac arrest during a practice at the University of Southern California. He was treated at a hospital and was in stable condition, his family said.
content: LeBron James Jr., the son of the Los Angeles Lakers star LeBron James who is an incoming freshman at the University of Southern California, collapsed at practice on Monday after suffering a cardiac arrest. James Jr., who is known as Bronny, was hospitalized in the intensive care unit but later released from the I.C.U. and is in stable condition, according to a statement from a spokesman for LeBron James and his wife, Savannah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Julie Turkewitz and Edgar Sandoval
title: How and Why Illegal Border Crossings Have Dropped So Dramatically
description: The Biden administration’s new asylum policy, which a judge blocked this week, has contributed to a plunge in illegal border crossings at the southern U.S. border.
content: In the 76 days since President Biden imposed tough new restrictions on the nation’s asylum system, the number of migrants crossing the United States’ southern border illegally every day has dropped significantly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Readers, Show Us Your Wit
description: Have a little fun by expressing your opinions in forms other than letters to the editor.
content: We invite readers to have a little fun by expressing their opinions in forms other than letters to the editor. Take a well-known song, poem or other kind of text (from Shakespeare to Seuss), and rewrite the words in response to something or someone in the news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haeryun Kang
title: North and South Korea Drift Farther Apart Every Day
description: Seventy years after the end of the Korean War, the two sides are as far apart as ever.
content: When North Korean forces surged across the 38th parallel in June 1950, starting the three-year Korean War, my grandfather Kang Yeon-gu was a teenage student on summer break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Britpop’s Back. But What Happened to Cool Britannia?
description: Some of the biggest ’90s bands are playing major gigs across Britain again, and headlining festivals abroad. Yet Britpop’s swaggering sense of national self-belief feels like a distant memory.
content: In 1994, Luis Chuva was 14 and on summer vacation at his grandparents’ home in Costa Nova, Portugal, when, one Saturday, he glimpsed something on TV that changed his life: a music video for “Girls and Boys,” by the British band Blur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Markets Trade Cautiously Ahead of Pivotal Fed Meeting
description: Stock markets often exhibit caution ahead of major events like Fed meetings, waiting until there is clarity over the central bank’s next move.
content: Stock markets slipped on Wednesday morning, as cautious investors parsed mixed earnings reports and prepared for the Federal Reserve to resume raising interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: A Pancaked Turtle Fossil’s 150-Million-Year-Old Tale
description: A beautifully preserved shelled reptile recovered from a Bavarian limestone deposit helps tell the story of how turtles first took to the seas.
content: Today it is Bavaria, a region of Germany. But in the Late Jurassic Period, it was a shallow tropical archipelago ringed with sponge reefs. The hyper-saline, oxygen-poor conditions of these waters prevented scavengers from disturbing the bodies of animals that died in the lagoons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Cannariato
title: What ‘The Bear’ Gets Right About Chicago
description: The show celebrates a kind of ambition — humane and independent — that’s often neglected by Hollywood. Maybe that’s why the setting is so important.
content: FX’s “The Bear,” now in its second season, is about grief and family and food, but there’s something else there, too. Its protagonist, Carmen Berzatto, is an accomplished chef who has worked in the vaunted kitchens of restaurants like Noma, the French Laundry and Eleven Madison Park. When the show began, he had come home to Chicago after the death of his brother, who left him a struggling shop selling a local staple, Italian beef sandwiches. Carmy could have run the place like any of the hundreds of modest lunch counters in the city, or else he could have sold it and angled to return to the world of fine dining. Instead, we watched him attempt a third thing, turning the business into a new, forward-thinking restaurant. This is the other stuff the show is about: ambition, and Chicago, and the freedom the nation’s third-largest city can offer to follow your ambitions on your own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: This Hummus Holds Up After 800 Years
description: First written down in the 13th century, this recipe has an enduring simplicity — but no garlic.
content: We do not eat quite like our ancestors. Gone from our tables are the roasted hedgehogs of Stone Age Britain and the flamingo tongues of ancient Rome. Nor do we know if, decades from now, our descendants will toast Pop-Tarts and dust steaks with edible gold. Or if the future climate will support agriculture of any kind, or human life at all — a scenario explored in C Pam Zhang’s eerily timely novel, “Land of Milk and Honey,” coming in September, in which deadly smog kills off nearly all the earth’s crops, forcing people to subsist on mung-bean powder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Republicans in Congress Seek to Block Hunter Biden’s Plea Deal
description: The chairman of the Ways and Means Committee filed a brief in federal court saying the plea agreement for the president’s son had been tainted by political interference.
content: On the eve of Hunter Biden’s court appearance to enter into a plea deal for misdemeanor tax crimes that would allow him to avoid prison time, House Republicans and conservative groups sought to intervene in the case, urging a judge to throw out the agreement he reached with prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Seeks a Nuclear-Powered Rocket to Get to Mars in Half the Time
description: The space agency and DARPA will work with Lockheed Martin to build a vehicle that uses the power of the atom for space propulsion.
content: In less than three years, NASA could be testing a nuclear rocket in space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Why I’m Rooting for Haiti
description: The 2023 Women’s World Cup has the largest field of competitors in tournament history. Les Grenadiers, as the Haitian team is known, may be the scrappiest of them all.
content: If you’ve read this column regularly over the last few years, my rooting interests should be clear by now. I pull for the outsiders and outliers. The strugglers and stragglers. The players and teams who toil hard for the simple chance, however slim, of winning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: ‘Oppenheimer’ and the Siren Song of World-Ending Technology
description: The story is a warning. Will we heed it?
content: Christopher Nolan’s blockbuster hit “Oppenheimer” tells the story of the father of the atomic bomb and the invention he hoped would end all wars. (Spoiler alert: It did not.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Kevin Spacey Found Not Guilty of Sexual Assault
description: A British jury on Wednesday found the actor not guilty of nine charges.
content: Kevin Spacey, the two-time Oscar-winning actor known for his movie and TV roles including “House of Cards,” was on Wednesday found not guilty by a jury in Britain of nine counts of sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, Adam Satariano and Aaron Krolik
title: Russia’s Online Censorship Has Soared 30-Fold During Ukraine War
description: A report from Citizen Lab laid out how much online censorship has increased on one of Russia’s biggest social media sites.
content: What’s the difference between Russia’s internet before and after the invasion of Ukraine? The answer: a thirtyfold increase in censorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Rise of Far Right Leaves Germany’s Conservatives at a Crossroads
description: The surge of the Alternative for Germany party has shaken the country’s political establishment. But for mainstream conservatives, it has also prompted an acute identity crisis.
content: Mario Voigt, a leader of Germany’s mainstream conservative party, has watched with concern the slow but steady string of victories notched by the far-right Alternative for Germany, known as the AfD.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Flipping a Switch and Making Cancers Self-Destruct
description: Researchers at Stanford devised a strange new molecule that could lead to drugs that arm genes and make cancers work against themselves.
content: Within every cancer are molecules that spur deadly, uncontrollable growth. What if scientists could hook those molecules to others that make cells self-destruct? Could the very drivers of a cancer’s survival instead activate the program for its destruction?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Wastewater Data Mirrored Covid Case Counts During First Omicron Wave
description: As Covid testing increasingly moved to the home, the wastewater data fell out of sync with case and hospitalization rates, a new study found.
content: Early last year, as the United States grappled with a record Covid-19 surge, the levels of coronavirus in a community’s wastewater were closely aligned with two other statistics that measured the toll of virus: local case and hospitalization rates. But by last fall, these measures had fallen out of sync, and the wastewater data was no longer such a good predictor of the officially reported case or hospitalization numbers, according to a new study, which was published in JAMA Network Open on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: A Looming Retraction Casts a Shadow Over a Field of Physics
description: Misconduct allegations are leading scientists to question the work of Ranga Dias, including his claimed discovery of a room-temperature superconductor.
content: A major physics journal is retracting a two-year-old scientific paper that described the transformations of a chemical compound as it was squeezed between two pieces of diamond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Sheet-Pan Chicken for Corn Season
description: Caramelized corn, pickled jalapeños and basil chicken make the most summery of sheet-pan dinners.
content: The beginning of corn season requires speed and simplicity. You want the fastest, easiest way to get that pile of evanescently sweet, nubby cobs on the table, ready for butter-slathering and gleeful chomping. A dip in boiling water, a quick sear on the grill or even a zap in the microwave all make the most of those fleeting first ears without much fuss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Paul Sonne
title: War Brought Putin Closer to Africa. Now It’s Pushing Them Apart.
description: As President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia prepares to host African leaders at a summit, a collapsed grain deal and the uncertain fate of Wagner mercenaries have cast a shadow.
content: Shunned in the West, his authority tested by a failed mutiny at home, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia needs to project normalcy and shore up support from his allies. So on Thursday, he will host African leaders at a flashy summit in St. Petersburg, part of his continuing outreach to a continent that has become critical to Moscow’s foreign policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Annihilation,’ ‘Support the Girls’ and More Streaming Gems
description: This month’s rundown of off-the-radar picks on your subscription streaming services includes indies of all stripes, plus three documentary explorations of our changing media landscape.
content: You’d think that a science-fiction adventure featuring the “Star Wars” alums Natalie Portman and Oscar Isaac, as well as Portman’s “Thor” co-star Tessa Thompson, would have been a giant hit. But Paramount Pictures seemed baffled by how to market a sci-fi picture about ideas and creeping dread (rather then lasers and intergalactic dogfights), dumping it onto Netflix overseas and into theaters with a shrug in the United States. They fear what they don’t understand; the writer and director Alex Garland, adapting the novel by Jeff VanderMeer, crafts a thrilling yet thoughtful combination of head trip and hero’s journey that owes more to Tarkovsky than Lucas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and Jeanna Smialek
title: Credit Markets Are Creaking, Creating Economic Uncertainty
description: Analysts warn that bankruptcies and defaults could jump as the world adjusts to higher interest rates.
content: Investors and economists have become optimistic that the Federal Reserve might successfully slow inflation without plunging the economy into recession, but many are still eyeing a risk that threatens to derail the effort: a tower of dicey-looking corporate debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I Am Estranged From My Toxic Mother. Should I Go on Her Birthday Trip?
description: A reader doesn’t want to upset his father, who requested his presence, but the idea of taking a vacation to celebrate a woman he has cut out of his life makes him squirm.
content: A year ago, I cut my toxic mother out of my life. It was a good decision. The problem: My father, whom I still see one on one, is distraught that I skip family events to avoid her. Now, he’s decided to pay for the whole family to go to an expensive resort to celebrate my mother’s 80th birthday, and he is pressuring me to join them. I think it would be hypocritical to go on vacation to celebrate a woman whom I no longer speak to. But my dad is 85. He has always been loving and supportive to me, and I know my being there would mean a lot to him. I’m torn: I don’t want to subject myself to my mother, but I don’t want to ruin the vacation for my father. Thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Taliban Shut Beauty Salons, One of Last Public Spaces for Afghan Women
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 26, 2023.
content: “This isn’t about getting your hair and nails done. This is about 60,000 women losing their jobs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: A Commitment to Green Policy Is Tested by an Election Win
description: British conservatives kept a seat in a recent election by opposing an ultralow emissions zone, and some are now questioning ambitious emissions-reduction targets.
content: Britain, blanketed by cool, damp weather, has seemed like one of the few places in the Northern Hemisphere not sweltering this summer. Yet a fierce political debate over how to curb climate change has suddenly erupted, fueled by economic hardship and a recent election surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Big Consumer Companies Keep Raising Prices, Complicating Fed’s Job
description: Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and Unilever have each reported raising prices significantly in the second quarter, complicating the Federal Reserve’s efforts to tame inflation.
content: Some of the largest consumer brands in the country have continued to raise prices aggressively this year while raking in large profits, posing a tough problem for the Federal Reserve as it aims to tame inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: How to Know When a Prosecution Is Political
description: Even if the subject is a politically powerful person or the outcome of a trial could have a political impact, that doesn’t necessarily mean the action itself is political.
content: As the criminal indictments of Donald Trump continue to pile up like boxes in a Mar-a-Lago bathroom, the former president’s defenders have settled on a response: They don’t claim their man is innocent of the scores of federal and state charges against him — a tough case to make under the circumstances. Instead they accuse the Biden administration and Democratic prosecutors of politicizing law enforcement and cooking up an insurance policy to protect President Biden, who trails Mr. Trump in some polls about a very possible 2024 rematch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Wagner Would Have Liked AR, but Not This ‘Parsifal’
description: Cutting-edge technology has again come to the Bayreuth Festival, where Wagner premiered his final opera with the latest stagecraft in 1882.
content: For Richard Wagner, the latest technology was crucial to staging his operas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greek Hotels Fear a Burning Future: ‘Even the Animals Are Moving Away’
description: The fiercest wildfires have hit only parts of a few islands. But the effects of climate change pose a far wider threat to Greece’s tourism industry.
content: As thousands of tourists have fled the flames devouring the Greek island of Rhodes, locals were left with scorched land, and the ashes of the cypresses, olive trees and pines surrounding their empty bars, shops and hotels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel’s High Court Says It Will Review Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul
description: The justices will hear petitions in September against a new law that curbs their own authority, which Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has pushed ahead despite Israel’s political turmoil.
content: Israel’s Supreme Court said Wednesday that it would review a contentious new law that diminishes the court’s own role, setting the stage for a constitutional crisis and renewed social turmoil if the judges end up overturning the legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: Ato Blankson-Wood on Playing a Hamlet Who ‘Leads With Love’
description: The actor is starring in a modern-dress production of the play through Aug. 6 at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.
content: As a veteran of the Public Theater’s free Shakespeare in the Park productions, Ato Blankson-Wood is used to contending with the elements. “The bugs, the helicopters flying overhead: There’s an intense focus that is necessary,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Barbie, the Doll and the Movie, Reflects Our Society
description: Readers react to all the media coverage of the doll’s influence. Also: Madison Square Garden; a path for Ukraine.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: The Solo Trip: Explore at Your Own Pace
description: Traveling alone can be rewarding, and a little daunting. Here’s how to get the most out of your trip, and stay safe, when you’re a party of one.
content: Solo travel has the power to transform: Think of the memoirs “Eat Pray Love” or “Wild.” But you don’t have to circumnavigate the globe or hike 1,100 miles to see why some people choose to go it alone. The freedom to explore at your own pace, open to connecting with people you meet along the way, can feel as intoxicating as a tropical breeze. But solo travel can be daunting, too, especially when problems arise. And of course, solo travelers need to keep certain safety considerations in mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Nikki Haley Answers a Thorny Abortion Question: Should Women Be Punished?
description: The former South Carolina governor — who is trying to break out in a packed 2024 Republican presidential primary — gave a nuanced response on one of the thorniest issues facing Republicans.
content: At town halls and political events in New Hampshire, where she has made far more campaign stops than her rivals, Nikki Haley has mostly sidestepped any discussion of abortion, a fraught issue for the Republican Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Family Died in Rockies After Trying to Live ‘Off the Grid,’ Official Says
description: Two sisters and a teenage son moved to a Colorado campsite last July, living off canned food. They had wanted to take a break from a world that distressed them, a local coroner said.
content: Last summer, Rebecca Vance talked with her family about a dream she’d had: She wanted to live in a land disconnected from the world, which she viewed as chaotic and dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Review: At Mostly Mozart, the Sense of an Ending
description: Louis Langrée, in his last season with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, conducted a classic Langrée program: Mozart and a premiere by Amir ElSaffar.
content: Change is coming for the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra and for its longtime music director, Louis Langrée — this month is the beginning of the end of his tenure with the orchestra. When the ensemble appears at Lincoln Center next year it will be with a freshly conceived name, and with the conductor Jonathon Heyward at the helm. (Heyward also leads the orchestra in concerts on Aug. 4 and 5.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Blistering Heat Spreads to U.S. Midwest as Wildfire Smoke Lingers
description: Midwestern residents sweltered in the heat wave that has scorched the South and Southwest for many days.
content: The heat wave that has scorched much of the American South and Southwest is now spreading through the Midwest, bringing temperatures above 100 degrees, dangerous conditions for millions of people and pleas from state and local officials to avoid spending time outdoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: 101°F in the Ocean Off Florida: Was It a World Record?
description: Measuring and comparing sea surface temperatures is complex, but scientists agree on one thing: A high reading this week is bad news for wildlife.
content: The reading from a buoy off Florida this week was stunning: 101.1 degrees Fahrenheit, or just over 38 Celsius, a possible world record for sea surface temperatures and a stark indication of the brutal marine heat wave that’s threatening the region’s sea life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: A Dusty Fast-Food Costume Sets Off a Very Canadian Bidding War
description: The government of Alberta is auctioning off an adult-size suit shaped like a donair, a uniquely Canadian take on the gyro and doner kebab that is a beloved late-night staple in Nova Scotia.
content: Josh Robinson, who grew up outside Halifax, Nova Scotia, can remember eating his first donair when he was around 7 years old, roughly two decades after the sandwich, composed of spiced, spit-roasted meat topped with a sweet sauce and wrapped in pita bread, first emerged as a regional delicacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Republican Attack Ads in Iowa Show Conservative Voters Who Turned on Trump
description: Hoping to persuade G.O.P. voters that Donald Trump cannot win another general election, the Republican Accountability Project is running ads that feature voters who grew disillusioned with him.
content: A Republican group that opposes Donald J. Trump is unveiling an advertising campaign featuring voters who supported him in the past two presidential elections but have now turned against him, in an effort to put questions of electability at the center of the G.O.P. primary race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: What You Can Do at Home to Help Stem Climate Change
description: Relatively simple measures like thermostat control, composting and switching to electric appliances can make a big difference.
content: Just the headlines from the past few weeks are enough to make a homeowner sweat:In Phoenix, the mercury has soared above 110 degrees every single day for three straight weeks. In Florida, Farmers Insurance has discontinued new policies, making it the latest in a string of insurance companies pulling out of the state in the past year. And in Arizona, where the Colorado River is shrinking dramatically, the rumble of new construction in one of America’s fastest-growing areas has gone silent after the governor put the brakes on new home-building, citing a lack of water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Delays and Cancellations: Know Your Rights
description: Advocating for yourself after an airline delay or cancellation can be challenging and confusing. Here’s how to best achieve the result you want — or at least get you where you want to go.
content: Flight delays and cancellations are unfortunate inevitabilities, especially in summer, when more people are flying and severe weather tends to occur more frequently.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Bo Goldman, Oscar-Winning Screenwriter, Dies at 90
description: He was a struggling writer when he won an Academy Award for “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.” He won another for “Melvin and Howard.”
content: Bo Goldman, one of Hollywood’s most admired screenwriters, who took home Oscars for his work on “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” (1975) and “Melvin and Howard” (1980), died on Tuesday in Helendale, Calif. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Giuliani Concedes He Made False Statements About Georgia Election Workers
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani said he still had “legal defenses” in a case brought by two election workers who said he had defamed them as he asserted that the 2020 election was marred by fraud.
content: Rudolph W. Giuliani has conceded that while acting as a lawyer for former President Donald J. Trump, he made false statements by asserting that two Georgia election workers had mishandled ballots while counting votes in Atlanta during the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner
title: For Adults With No Heart Attack or Stroke History, Evidence Says Not to Start Baby Aspirin
description: A new analysis of older people who have never had a heart attack or stroke suggests limited protective power of daily low-dose aspirin, and worrisome side effects.
content: A new analysis of data from a large clinical trial of healthy older adults found higher rates of brain bleeding among those who took daily low-dose aspirin, and no significant protection against stroke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Easterling
title: Rocky Wirtz, Chairman of N.H.L.’s Chicago Blackhawks, Dies at 70
description: Wirtz assumed control of the team after his father’s death in 2007. He helped bring the team to prominence, but the mishandling of an assault accusation dimmed that success.
content: W. Rockwell Wirtz, nicknamed Rocky, the chairman of the N.H.L.’s Chicago Blackhawks, died on Tuesday at age 70.

title: How Hunter Biden’s Judge Came to Have Doubts on the Deal
description: In just a few hours, Judge Maryellen Noreika exposes a gulf in understanding between the president’s son and prosecutors on an agreement they had spent weeks hashing out.
content: Judge Maryellen Noreika kicked off Wednesday’s hearing on Hunter Biden’s proposed plea deal with the Justice Department by telling lawyers that they did not need to keep “popping” up and down every time she asked them a question.

author: By Dani Blum
title: A Simple 14-Minute Workout That Could Lower Your Blood Pressure
description: A new study points to the humble wall squat as the most effective tool to fight hypertension.
content: It has become almost a cliché across doctor’s offices: One of the most trusted tools to lower blood pressure is to exercise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Raises Rates After a Pause and Leaves Door Open to More
description: Federal Reserve officials lifted borrowing costs by a quarter-point after pausing in June. Rates could rise more, but the central bank is not ready to commit.
content: Federal Reserve officials raised interest rates to their highest level in 22 years and left the door open to further action as they continued their 16-month campaign to wrestle inflation lower by cooling the American economy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Crane Partially Collapses in Midtown Manhattan, Injuring 11
description: Nine civilians and two firefighters were hurt when the crane on 10th Avenue collapsed, officials said.
content: In a dramatic scene, a construction crane atop a high-rise building in Midtown Manhattan burst into flames and partially collapsed onto the street on Wednesday morning, injuring 11 people, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Carlotta Gall
title: Main Thrust of Ukraine’s Offensive May Be Underway, U.S. Officials Say
description: After holding back many of its units trained and armed by the West, Ukraine is now committing them, the officials said, but it remained unclear whether a full-scale assault was taking place.
content: Ukraine has launched the main thrust of its counteroffensive, throwing in thousands of troops held in reserve, many of them Western-trained and equipped, two Pentagon officials said on Wednesday, hours after Russian officials reported major Ukrainian attacks in the southern Zaporizhzhia region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 1 Dead and 22 Injured in Cargo Ship Fire Off the Netherlands
description: The ship was carrying nearly 3,000 vehicles near the Dutch island of Ameland in the North Sea when the fire was reported late Tuesday, officials said.
content: One crew member has died and 22 others have been injured in a fire on a large cargo vessel loaded with nearly 3,000 vehicles off the Dutch island of Ameland in the North Sea, officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims
title: The Friend Trip: Fun Without the Friction
description: Sometimes even best buds have trouble making travel plans together or splitting costs, but there are some ways you can take that big trip without a major falling-out.
content: Whoever said a friend is a friend forever has clearly never experienced a group trip that has devolved into a maelstrom of conflicting plans and bickering over restaurant bills. Traveling with your besties can be tricky. Here are some ways to do it without anyone getting unfriended.

title: Your Thursday Briefing: Ukraine Launches Full Offensive
description: Also, Cambodian succession, Sinead O’Connor’s death and a lemon bar recipe.
content: Two U.S. officials said that the main thrust of Ukraine’s counteroffensive is now underway in the southeast. The Russian Defense Ministry also reported a “massive” assault in the region.

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: The Whales Gathered in a Heart Shape. Experts Feared What Would Come Next.
description: A pod of nearly 100 pilot whales displayed unusual behavior before beaching themselves in Australia. More than 50 died, and the rest were later euthanized.
content: The pod of pilot whales huddled together for nearly a full day in the shallow waters off a remote beach in Western Australia. At times it made the shape of a circle, or spread into a line, or even, for a few moments, formed a loose heart shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Simpson Kalisher, Photographer Who Captured Urban Grit, Dies at 96
description: He emerged from a largely commercial background to join the towering figures who defined an art form — street photography — in the 1950s and ’60s
content: Simpson Kalisher, who liberated his lens from slick images in corporate reports and trade magazines to emerge as a discerning photojournalist whose street scenes froze the panorama of urban American life in the 1950s and ’60s, died on June 13 at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Shinar
title: In Israel, the Worst May Be Yet to Come
description: The right-wing coalition’s hobbling of the Supreme Court is just the start of a campaign against the country’s democratic foundations.
content: TEL AVIV — Many Israelis are bracing for what comes next. Anger over a bill that eliminates the courts’ power to overturn government and ministerial decisions on grounds of reasonableness, and the constitutional overhaul of which it’s part, had set off huge protests for seven months. Just before the bill’s passage on Monday, more than 1,100 air force reservists, including more than 400 pilots, declared that they would refuse to turn up for duty if the legislation was approved. In the aftermath of the vote, tens of thousands of protesters, in a collective cry of rage, blocked highways, shut down major intersections, and confronted a police force intent on dispersing them with horses, water cannons and brute force. Dozens were arrested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooke Jarvis
title: The Fight for the Right to Trespass
description: A group of English activists want to legally enshrine the “right to roam” — and spread the idea that nature is a common good.
content: The signs on the gate at the entrance to the path and along the edge of the reservoir were clear. “No swimming,” they warned, white letters on a red background.

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: 3 Marines Found in Car at Gas Station Died of Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
description: Autopsy results on Wednesday revealed the cause of death.
content: Three Marines who were found dead on Sunday inside a car parked at a gas station in Hampstead, N.C., died of carbon monoxide poisoning, the authorities said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kin Woo
title: A Vibrant Vegan Dinner on the British Coast
description: The musician and chef Denai Moore and the photographer and designer Ronan Mckenzie launched their new projects with a Jamaican-inspired meal.
content: On a balmy recent evening, the Carl Freedman Gallery in the English coastal town of Margate was the setting for a double celebration. Fourteen guests gathered to mark both the opening of “To Be Held” — a group show curated by the filmmaker, photographer and fashion designer Ronan Mckenzie — and the launch of “Plentiful,” the debut cookbook by the Jamaican-born British musician and vegan chef Denai Moore. The two honorees first met at a vegan cafe in London in 2019, where they bonded over their shared Caribbean heritage (Mckenzie’s family is from Barbados) and approach to their creative pursuits. “The foundations we come from are quite similar,” said Mckenzie. “In our practices, there’s a sense of connection through shared experience.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Friend Is Mistreating Her Nanny. Should I Say Something?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the social costs of speaking up about an unjust situation.
content: My friend’s nanny is good friends with my own nanny. Over the years, my nanny has told me about instances when my friend has mistreated nannies she has hired — withholding food, refusing payment for extra work and reneging on benefits she agreed to. This friend displays nothing but lovely behavior toward me and our other friends, but knowing how she treats her nannies is increasingly disturbing me, to the point where I don’t think I can be friends with her and not say anything about what I know. This friend introduced me to her circle of friends a few years ago, and it’s because of her that I am part of a great group of women. Should I intervene and risk her behaving even worse toward her nannies and creating a rift in the friend circle? Or do I say nothing and continue with business as usual? — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: How Regional Banks Got Healthy Again
description: The crisis set off by Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse has waned. Its peers have more capital and deeper customer ties.
content: After depositor runs led to the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank this spring, investors and onlookers wondered how similarly sized institutions would fare. Would they have to merge with bigger banks? Break up their businesses and shrink drastically? Or were more of them simply doomed?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Wei-Haas
title: When Ancient Eruptions Pumped Diamonds to Earth’s Surface
description: A new study offers clues to the mysteries of kimberlite eruptions, the source of most of the diamonds mined on Earth today.
content: While diamonds might look pretty perched atop a ring, the rocks they hail from venture to Earth’s surface in a journey that’s anything but glamorous. Millions of years ago, some of our planet’s strangest and most violent volcanic outbursts dredged from deep underground most of the diamonds mined today in the form of blue-tinged rocks called kimberlites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Mayor Eric Adams to Name New Chief Counsel Amid Migrant and Rikers Crises
description: Lisa Zornberg, who oversaw high-profile and complex cases, is arriving as Mayor Eric Adams develops policies to address several crises.
content: Lisa Zornberg, a lawyer in private practice and a former senior Manhattan federal prosecutor, will return to public service as chief counsel to Mayor Eric Adams, the mayor said Wednesday.

title: McCarthy, Pressured by the Right, Escalates Talk of Impeaching Biden
description: The speaker’s comments came on the eve of a hearing in the tax case against Hunter Biden, and ahead of a potential third indictment of former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy, under pressure from the hard right to take aggressive steps against the Biden administration, suggested on Tuesday that the House was moving toward opening an impeachment inquiry against President Biden, as Republicans search through bank records hunting for damaging information about the first family.

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: What Higher Interest Rates Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
description: Savers benefit from higher rates, but borrowers have faced bigger bills on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
content: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates on Wednesday, the latest in a series of increases that have squeezed the budgets of debt-laden Americans, while rewarding those with money to stash in savings.

author: By Peter Coy
title: Companies Aren’t Eager to Cut Their Prices as Costs Fall
description: Prices that go up don’t necessarily have to come down.
content: “Rockets and feathers” is economists’ name for how prices change in some less-than-competitive markets. When companies’ input costs go up for some reason, the prices they charge their customers go up like a rocket. When their input costs go back down, their prices fall, but ever so slowly, like a feather. The example most of us can relate to is the retail price of gasoline.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Won’t Simon Ateba Stop Shouting?
description: The Today News Africa gadfly has become a hero on the right, thanks to his confrontational behavior in the White House briefing room.

content: The Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise interest rates at its meeting on Wednesday, and economists will be watching for hints at what officials expect next — and how they think the central bank’s fight against rapid inflation is going.

title: How Fake Science Sells Wellness
description: Dubious claims in product marketing are everywhere. Don’t fall for them.
content: You can’t browse a grocery store or pharmacy without being subject to flashy labels that promote health benefits. In the beverage aisle, for example, you might find “prebiotic” sodas that supposedly support “gut health.” In the beauty department, you’ll see “medical-grade” serums, “probiotic” facial creams and “skin detoxing” treatments. Go to the supplements section for promises of “immunity support,” “hormone balance” and “energy enhancement,” among other things.

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $550,000 Homes in Virginia, Oklahoma and Maine
description: An 1820 townhouse in Portsmouth, a 1940 home in Oklahoma City and a Colonial Revival house in Westbrook.
content: This house is in the city’s Olde Towne historic district, on a street with brick sidewalks a few blocks from the waterfront. It is within walking distance of the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard Museum, the Children’s Museum of Virginia and a ferry terminal with boats departing for Norfolk. The Portsmouth Art & Cultural Center, a 1945 Art Deco-style movie theater and the city’s welcome center are also nearby, on High Street.

title: In Milan, Giving the Aperitivo a New Twist
description: The nightly cocktail ritual is central to the Italian city’s culture. Here’s where to find both the classic bitters-based drinks and new spins on them.
content: To understand how central the aperitivo is to Milan culture, you need only stand in the middle of the Piazza del Duomo, the city’s pulsing center, and face the cathedral. To your right you’ll see a huge version of the Martini vermouth logo glowing atop a modest skyscraper in nearby Piazza Armando Diaz. At its top is the rooftop bar Terrazza Martini. content: The Transportation Department announced on Wednesday that it had finalized new regulations to require more commercial aircraft to have accessible bathrooms, a long-awaited step to address complaints from disabled travelers about the difficulties of flying.

title: The Covid Origins Debate
description: The picture has changed as more evidence emerges, but we might never get a clear answer.
content: Did Covid jump from an animal to a person at a food market in Wuhan, China — or leak from a research lab there? That question remains the pandemic’s central mystery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: What You Should Know About the Potential Risks of Kratom
description: The herbal product remains widely available, despite lawsuits and warnings from health authorities.
content: Across gas stations, smoke shops and the internet, consumers can easily buy kratom — an herbal substance that some users claim is an antidote to opioid dependence and a lifeline for alleviating mental and physical pain. In 2021 alone, roughly 1.7 million Americans used kratom, although the F.D.A. has not approved it for any medical use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Hun Sen, One of World’s Longest-Serving Rulers, to Step Down Next Month
description: Mr. Hun Sen, whose party won stage-managed parliamentary elections on Sunday, has been prime minister of Cambodia since 1985. He said he would hand power to his son.
content: Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia, one of the world’s longest-serving leaders, said on Wednesday that he would resign next month and hand power to his son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A Brexit Champion’s Feud With His Elite Bank Brings a C.E.O. Down
description: Nigel Farage, a political insurgent and ally of Donald J. Trump, exposed his bank for dropping him over “reputational risks.” Some analysts say he could parlay his situation into a comeback.
content: When Nigel Farage campaigned for a fellow populist, Donald J. Trump, in 2020, he seemed like a faded star seeking the spotlight abroad after it had swung past him at home. Mr. Farage, who helped mobilize the pro-Brexit vote in 2016, was marginalized in Britain, then consumed by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang W. Lee and Choe Sang-Hun
title: Life Along the Korean DMZ, 70 Years After the Fighting Ended
description: The Korean War Armistice was signed seventy years ago, separating the two Koreas and putting an end to the fighting, but not the war itself.
content: Seen from the sky, the Demilitarized Zone, or DMZ, looks like a gigantic geographical wound across the Korean Peninsula, the continuous wire fences snaking up the hills and down the valleys from coast to coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Restaurateur Who Paid Off New York Politicians Sentenced to 4 Years in Prison
description: Harendra Singh pleaded guilty to bribing the former executive of Nassau County, and admitted he also tried to bribe former Mayor Bill de Blasio.
content: A Long Island restaurateur who was a key witness in a public corruption investigation was sentenced to four years in prison Wednesday, ending an episode that churned up allegations of endemic wrongdoing that stretched across New York City and one of its most populous suburban areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Why Legacy Admissions Are at the Center of a Dispute in Higher Education
description: Systems that give preference to children of alumni are under renewed scrutiny after the Supreme Court issued a ruling against affirmative action.
content: The U.S. Supreme Court ruling gutting race-conscious admissions last month placed a spotlight on legacy preferences in higher education, a practice that mostly helps white and wealthy students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Michael S. Schmidt and Chris Cameron
title: Judge Puts Hunter Biden’s Plea Deal on Hold, Questioning Its Details
description: Judge Maryellen Noreika sent the two sides back to try to work out modifications that would address her legal and constitutional concerns and salvage the basic contours of the agreement.
content: A federal judge on Wednesday put on hold a proposed plea deal between Hunter Biden and the Justice Department that would have settled tax and gun charges against the president’s son, stunning the courtroom and raising legal and constitutional questions about the agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rikki Novetsky, Stella Tan, Michael Simon Johnson, Sydney Harper, Mary Wilson, Rachel Quester, Michael Benoist, John Ketchum, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: Hunter Biden’s Day in Court
description: A yearslong federal investigation has ended with the president’s son agreeing to plead guilty to tax misdemeanors.
content: On Wednesday morning, Hunter Biden was scheduled to a guilty plea in a Delaware courtroom, marking the end of a yearslong federal investigation that many Republicans believed would put the president’s son in prison, and put an end to the Biden presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Barboncino, a Brooklyn Pizza Restaurant, Becomes a Union Shop
description: Staff at this Crown Heights restaurant voted to join Workers United, making the pizzeria New York City’s first to have a unionized staff.
content: Barboncino, a Neapolitan-style pizza restaurant in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, has become the first unionized pizzeria in New York City after its workers unanimously voted to approve the formation of a union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Real College Admissions Scandal
description: We need to end legacy admissions and look beyond the Ivy League if we’re going to fix our unequal education system.
content: YAMHILL, Ore. — Before I make an argument about affirmative action, let me tell you how I was a beneficiary of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Gov. Abbott’s Policing of Texas Border Pushes Limits of State Power
description: The governor brought in razor wire, floating barriers and state troopers to deter unauthorized migration. The federal government mounted its first legal pushback this week.
content: Along Texas’ 1,200-mile-long border with Mexico, state troopers routinely arrest migrants for trespassing. Texas National Guard troops unspool razor wire along the banks of the Rio Grande. State game wardens patrol the river in fast-moving boats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Omar Hama Saley, Elian Peltier and Declan Walsh
title: Military in Niger Announces Coup After Soldiers Detain President
description: President Mohamed Bazoum was one of the West’s most reliable partners in a volatile region threatened by militant extremists and prone to coups.
content: Military officers in the West African nation of Niger ousted the country’s president on Wednesday, they said in an address on national television, throwing into uncertainty the future of one of the West’s few reliable partners in a region marred by coups and widespread insecurity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mueller
title: A Fight to Save Soldiers, From the Lab to the Battlefield
description: “In the Blood” traces how an engineer and a salesman took on military leaders and Big Pharma to get a revolutionary clotting agent to those in dire need.
content: Reading, like riding shotgun with a stranger, is an act of faith, whose first moments matter. An accurate, judicious beginning often allows us to settle back and enjoy the ride, whereas an early slip or swerve means we might be white-knuckling the rest of the journey. Charles Barber’s “In the Blood” treats a consequential topic, and contains moments of real insight, drama and humor. Trouble is, Barber opens with several omissions and slights that left me on edge for the balance of the book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Internet Trolls Propelled Prigozhin’s Rise. Now Some Celebrate His Fall.
description: The Kremlin, which has moved quickly to take down parts of Wagner leader Yevgeny Prigozhin’s empire, may seek to use his troll farms to its advantage, analysts say.
content: When President Vladimir V. Putin said recently that the Wagner mercenary group legally “does not exist,” a collection of social media accounts that have historically been associated with Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the group’s founder, quickly endorsed the Russian leader’s statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: White House Condemns Fox News Over Host’s Holocaust Comments
description: In a debate over Florida’s African American history curriculum, Greg Gutfeld said Jews in Nazi concentration camps “had to be useful” to survive, remarks that the White House called “an obscenity.”
content: The White House denounced Fox News this week over comments by one of its hosts, Greg Gutfeld, that some Jews “had to be useful” as a means for survival in Nazi concentration camps, calling his remarks “an obscenity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: G.M. and Other Automakers Will Build 30,000 Electric Vehicle Chargers
description: The companies will jointly spend at least $1 billion to build a North American network in an effort to persuade more people to buy battery-powered cars and trucks.
content: Seven major automakers announced a plan on Wednesday to nearly double the number of fast chargers in the United States in an effort to address one of the main reasons that people hesitate to buy electric cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Colonization Was the ‘Luckiest Thing’ to Happen to Australia, Ex-Leader Says
description: The backlash was swift after John Howard made the remarks ahead of a referendum on Aboriginal representation in the government.
content: A former prime minister of Australia has stirred a storm of outrage by describing colonization as “the luckiest thing that happened to this country” and praising Britain for being a better overlord than other nations ahead of a contentious referendum on Aboriginal representation in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 26, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 26, 2023.
content: An article on Sunday about the pharmaceutical industry’s attempt to halt a federal drug pricing program described incorrectly the reason that Medicare’s reported spending per patient for two blood thinners in 2021 was lower than their sticker prices. The lower amount reflected that some patients took the drugs for less than a full year. It did not reflect discounts negotiated by pharmacy benefit managers, which were not factored into the spending figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: A Prominent Bank C.E.O. Exits Amid a Political Storm in Britain
description: Alison Rose of NatWest, one of the country’s largest banks, resigned after Nigel Farage, a Brexit firebrand, said his account had been shut because of his political views.
content: Alison Rose, the chief executive of NatWest, one of Britain’s largest banks, resigned on Wednesday, just weeks after becoming embroiled in a dispute over the closure of the bank account of Nigel Farage, who is best known as a champion of Britain’s exit from the European Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Bald Power of Sinead O’Connor
description: The Irish singer’s shaved head was as much a part of her identity and allure as her sound.
content: It was the bald head that became the avatar of a million dreamy rebellions; the shaved pate that bridged the gap between the angry and the sublime. It is almost impossible to think about Sinead O’Connor, the Irish singer whose death was reported on July 26, or her work, without thinking about her hair. Or lack of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Replacing Your Lawn? Instead of a Meadow, Consider a Food Forest.
description: Or just start by planting a few pawpaw or persimmon trees. Chances are, you’ll want more.
content: Your first taste of a ripe pawpaw or persimmon can leave you hungry for more. That’s why Michael Judd is confident that he can persuade you to make room for several of these trees in your front yard — or even to surrender your lawn altogether.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Harbor Porpoises Are Here, Putting Up With the Noise
description: Like seasoned New Yorkers, the porpoises have adapted to the sounds troubling their universe. Also, investigators find an arsenal at the Gilgo Beach suspect’s home.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll find out about harbor porpoises, which have made New York a year-round destination — to the surprise of researchers who tracked them. We’ll also see what investigators found at the Long Island home of the architect charged in the Gilgo Beach killings.

author: By Lisa Lerer and Katie Rogers
title: The Very Private Life of Melania Trump
description: The former first lady has mostly retreated from public view — and steered clear of the campaign trail — while her husband fights to return to the White House and faces increasing legal peril.
content: Since leaving the White House, Melania Trump’s world has gotten smaller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Amy Harmon
title: Affirmative Action Ruling Shakes Universities Over More Than Race
description: At what was billed as an Education Department “summit” in Washington on Wednesday, a wide range of college admissions practices were on the table.
content: The Supreme Court’s decision to effectively end race-conscious admissions in higher education last month was historic in its own right, removing a tool that the nation’s colleges have used for decades to increase racial diversity on their campuses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How George Santos Used Political Connections to Fuel Get-Rich Schemes
description: Mr. Santos, a first-term House member under federal indictment, often tried to use his candidacy and ties to Republican donors to create moneymaking opportunities.
